name: Holi
title: Festival of Colors - Rangwali Holi
description: Holi is a vibrant spring festival celebrating love, joy, and the triumph of good over evil. Known as the Festival of Colors, it marks the arrival of spring and the end of winter.
significance: Celebrates the divine love of Radha and Krishna, and commemorates the victory of devotee Prahlad over the demoness Holika.

seo.description: Complete guide to Holi festival with colors, rituals, stories, bhajans, recipes, and celebrations. Learn the significance of Festival of Colors.

sections.title: Welcome to Holi
sections.content: Holi, the festival of colors, is one of the most joyous Hindu festivals celebrated with great enthusiasm across India and worldwide. This two-day festival signifies the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil.

sections.title: Historical Significance
sections.content: Holi has ancient origins and is mentioned in Hindu scriptures. The festival celebrates various divine events including the divine love of Radha and Krishna, and the victory of Prahlad over Holika.

sections.title: Famous Stories
sections.content: Holi is associated with several important stories from Hindu mythology, each teaching valuable lessons about good triumphing over evil.

subsections.title: Prahlad and Holika
subsections.content: The story of Holi begins with the demon king Hiranyakashipu, who wanted everyone to worship only him. However, his son Prahlad was a devoted follower of Lord Vishnu. Enraged, Hiranyakashipu asked his sister Holika, who had a boon to remain unburnt by fire, to sit in a pyre with Prahlad on her lap. However, because of Prahlad's devotion and Holika's evil intentions, she was burned while Prahlad remained safe.

subsections.title: Krishna and Radha's Love
subsections.content: Another beloved story is of young Krishna, who was self-conscious about his dark complexion compared to fair Radha. His mother Yashoda playfully suggested he could color Radha's face any color he wanted. Krishna took this advice and started the tradition of playing with colors during Holi.

sections.title: How Holi is Celebrated
sections.content: Holi celebrations span two days with different rituals and traditions.

subsections.title: Day 1: Holika Dahan
subsections.content: The first evening is celebrated as Holika Dahan, where people gather to perform rituals around a bonfire. The bonfire symbolizes the burning of evil and the victory of good.

subsections.title: Day 2: Rangwali Holi
subsections.content: The second day is the main Holi celebration where people play with colors, water guns, and water balloons. Everyone dances, sings, and celebrates with joy and enthusiasm.

sections.title: Rituals and Traditions
sections.content: Holi is celebrated with various rituals that vary by region but share common themes of joy and celebration.

subsections.title: Holika Dahan Ritual
subsections.content: People collect wood and other combustible materials for the bonfire. They perform rituals around the fire, offering prayers and seeking blessings for prosperity.

subsections.title: Playing with Colors
subsections.content: People apply dry colors (gulal) and wet colors on each other's faces. Water guns (pichkaris) and water balloons are used to splash colored water.

sections.title: Holi Special Foods
sections.content: Holi celebrations are incomplete without traditional sweets and drinks.

subsections.title: Traditional Sweets
subsections.content: Popular Holi sweets include Gujiya, Mathri, Malpua, and Kheer. These sweets are prepared in advance and shared with friends and family.

subsections.title: Special Drinks
subsections.content: Bhang and Thandai are traditional Holi drinks. Bhang is made from cannabis leaves and is consumed during Holi celebrations.

sections.title: Holi Bhajans
sections.content: Devotional songs sung during Holi to celebrate the divine love of Radha and Krishna.
